p.s: Shakespeare is one of the most famous poets and nowadays even German students knowsknow him but it wasn't always like that – in fact it took almost 200 years.
It is not a secret that Shakespeare became famous thanks to his poetic work but in Germany people mostly did not know him for a long time because there were simply no translation available.
In a German newspaper article Wolfgang Hirsch describes how the poet finally found his way to Germany and why the city Weimar plays an important role in it.
The first extensive translation of Shakespearean drama was published by Christoph Martin Wieland in Zürich in 1762-1766.

While also other importentimportant German poets tried to introduce or work with Shakespearean drama this was the start of it'sits spreading and even though there are now many different versions of translations Wieland is still very respected for the poetic power he put into it by for example the German professor Klaus Mayer who is quoted in the article.
But what role did Weimar play in all of it?
Well, after the publishing of Wieland's work it was in Weimar on 8 April 1864 that ShakespearShakespeare was performed in a theatre for the first time.
The histories directed by Franz von Dingestedt were so impressive that at the same day the oldest German literary organization, the Shakespeare society, was founded.

And as the admiration of the famous poet continued in Weimar and spreaded through all of Germany even a statue of Shakespeare by Otto Lessing was put up as the first one in Europe in 1904 and is now protected by the UNESCOUnited Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization.
So all in all, even though it took a long time for Shakespeare to reach Germany he did influence it a lot once the city of Weimar spreaded his work.
How did Shakespeare's work arrive in your country and is he still relevant?
